title: CNS Vasculitis (PACNS)
scope: ** Diagnosis, immunosuppressive treatment, and long-term monitoring of primary angiitis of the central nervous system (PACNS). Covers the classic triad (headache, cognitive decline, focal deficits), CSF analysis, MRI findings, conventional angiography, brain biopsy indications and limitations, induction immunosuppression (high-dose corticosteroids plus cyclophosphamide), maintenance immunosuppression (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil), and serial monitoring. Includes differentiation from reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS), secondary CNS vasculitis (SLE, sarcoidosis, infection-related), and other stroke mimics. For systemic vasculitis with CNS involvement, use the specific systemic vasculitis template. For RCVS, use "RCVS" template if available. For ischemic stroke management, use "Acute Ischemic Stroke" template.

Extended.item: Conventional cerebral angiography (digital subtraction angiography, DSA) (CPT 36224)
Extended.timing: Within 48-72 hours; URGENT if high clinical suspicion
Extended.target: Beading pattern (alternating stenosis and dilation); segmental narrowing; vessel wall irregularity; microaneurysms; occlusion; slow flow. NOTE: Normal angiogram does NOT exclude PACNS (sensitivity 40-90%; may miss small vessel disease)

Extended.item: MRI brain with vessel wall imaging (VWI) (CPT 70553)
Extended.target: Concentric vessel wall enhancement (suggests vasculitis); eccentric enhancement (suggests atherosclerosis); mural thickening; vessel wall edema. Helps distinguish vasculitis from RCVS, atherosclerosis, and intracranial dissection

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology or cerebrovascular specialist) for PACNS diagnosis confirmation, immunotherapy initiation, and long-term management
Rheumatology for exclusion of systemic vasculitis and co-management of immunosuppressive therapy
Neurosurgery for brain biopsy when non-invasive workup is non-diagnostic and tissue diagnosis is required before committing to long-term immunosuppression
Neuroradiology (interventional) for conventional cerebral angiography with vasculitis protocol and vessel wall imaging interpretation
Infectious disease for exclusion of infectious vasculitis (VZV, syphilis, TB, fungal) and infection management during immunosuppression
Hematology/oncology if intravascular lymphoma or lymphomatoid granulomatosis suspected based on imaging or biopsy findings
Ophthalmology for fundoscopic examination to assess for retinal vasculitis (may support PACNS diagnosis) and steroid-related complications
Physical therapy for motor rehabilitation, gait training, and fall prevention given stroke-like deficits
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive rehabilitation, and adaptive strategies for functional recovery
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation and cognitive-linguistic therapy if aphasia or cognitive deficits present
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive assessment given cognitive decline as a hallmark of PACNS; serial monitoring to track treatment response
Social work for insurance navigation, disability resources, and family support during prolonged treatment course
Endocrinology for steroid-induced diabetes management if persistent hyperglycemia on corticosteroid therapy
Reproductive endocrinology/fertility specialist for fertility preservation counseling before cyclophosphamide initiation in patients of reproductive age
Palliative care for goals of care discussion in severe refractory disease or significant treatment complications

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new or worsening headache, sudden weakness, speech difficulty, vision changes, or seizures (may indicate disease relapse or new CNS ischemia)
Do not stop corticosteroids abruptly as this may cause adrenal crisis and disease flare; taper must be supervised by neurology
Report signs of infection promptly (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash, mouth sores) while on immunosuppressive therapy, as infection risk is significantly increased
Avoid live vaccines during immunosuppressive therapy (MMR, varicella, zoster live, yellow fever, intranasal influenza); inform all healthcare providers of immunosuppressed status
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to risk of seizures and cognitive impairment
Take cyclophosphamide in the morning with at least 2 liters of fluids daily to reduce bladder toxicity; empty bladder frequently
Expect prolonged treatment course (months to years); adherence to maintenance immunosuppression is essential to prevent relapse
Pregnancy must be avoided during cyclophosphamide and mycophenolate therapy; discuss contraception with neurology and OB/GYN before starting treatment
Wear medical alert bracelet identifying immunosuppressed status and PACNS diagnosis
Report any new neurological symptoms between scheduled visits, including subtle cognitive changes, as early relapse detection improves outcomes
Attend all scheduled follow-up appointments including MRI surveillance and laboratory monitoring for treatment safety
Avoid excessive sun exposure while on immunosuppressive therapy due to increased skin cancer risk; use sunscreen SPF 30+

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve treatment response; smoking worsens endothelial dysfunction
Blood pressure target <140/90 mmHg (lower if tolerated) to reduce cerebrovascular risk and prevent further ischemic injury
Low-sodium diet to manage steroid-induced fluid retention and hypertension
Regular weight-bearing exercise as tolerated to maintain bone density during prolonged corticosteroid therapy; target 150 min/week of moderate activity
Adequate hydration (minimum 2L/day) during cyclophosphamide therapy to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis
Pneumococcal (PCV20) and annual influenza vaccination (inactivated only) before or during immunosuppression when possible; avoid live vaccines
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards given potential for cognitive impairment and motor deficits
Cognitive stimulation activities (reading, puzzles, social engagement) to support cognitive recovery alongside formal rehabilitation
Stress management and psychological support given chronic disease diagnosis; referral to support groups for vasculitis patients

differential.features: Thunderclap headache (acute, maximal at onset); diffuse segmental vasoconstriction that RESOLVES within 12 weeks; normal or near-normal CSF; triggers (vasoactive drugs, postpartum, exertion); younger females; typically self-limited
differential.tests: Repeat angiography at 12 weeks (RCVS normalizes; PACNS persists or worsens); CSF normal in RCVS vs. abnormal in 80% of PACNS; vessel wall imaging (smooth non-enhancing walls in RCVS vs. concentric enhancement in PACNS)

differential.features: Risk factors (age, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia); focal stenosis rather than multifocal beading; no CSF abnormalities; no systemic inflammation
differential.tests: CSF normal; conventional angiography pattern; vessel wall imaging (eccentric enhancement in atherosclerosis vs. concentric in vasculitis); vascular risk factors

differential.features: Multifocal strokes; progressive cognitive decline; B symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats); elevated LDH; skin involvement
differential.tests: Brain biopsy (gold standard -- atypical lymphocytes within vessel lumina); CSF flow cytometry; FDG-PET; skin biopsy if lesions present

differential.features: Mass lesion (often periventricular); ring enhancement; restricted diffusion; steroid-responsive (may mimic vasculitis improvement)
differential.tests: Brain biopsy; CSF cytology and flow cytometry; FDG-PET hypermetabolism; steroid response then rebound

differential.diagnosis: Systemic vasculitis with CNS involvement (SLE, GPA, polyarteritis nodosa, Behcet)
differential.features: Systemic features (rash, arthritis, renal disease, lung involvement); elevated inflammatory markers; positive serologic markers
differential.tests: ANA, ANCA, complement, anti-dsDNA; renal biopsy; skin biopsy; CT chest; targeted systemic workup

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (especially CN VII); hypothalamic/pituitary dysfunction; basilar leptomeningeal enhancement; hilar lymphadenopathy on chest imaging
differential.tests: ACE level (serum and CSF); chest CT (bilateral hilar adenopathy); biopsy (non-caseating granulomas); FDG-PET

differential.features: Progressive bilateral ICA stenosis with basal collateral network (puff of smoke on angiography); children and young adults; East Asian predominance; no CSF abnormalities
differential.tests: MRA/DSA (bilateral ICA stenosis with moyamoya vessels); normal CSF; normal inflammatory markers; vessel wall imaging (no enhancement)

differential.features: Lobar hemorrhages; older age (>65); cortical superficial siderosis; white matter changes; no CSF inflammation unless ABRA variant
differential.tests: MRI (lobar microbleeds on SWI/GRE); Boston criteria; biopsy if ABRA suspected (granulomatous vasculitis with amyloid)

differential.features: Recurrent arterial/venous thrombosis; pregnancy losses; livedo reticularis; Libman-Sacks endocarditis; multifocal infarcts
differential.tests: Anticardiolipin, anti-beta2-glycoprotein I, lupus anticoagulant (confirmed on repeat testing 12 weeks apart); no CSF inflammation

differential.features: Recent or remote zoster; immunocompromised; may mimic PACNS closely; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis with positive VZV antibodies
differential.tests: CSF VZV PCR and VZV IgG (antibody index more sensitive than PCR); responds to IV acyclovir; MRI may show deep infarcts

differential.features: History of syphilis or high-risk exposure; cranial neuropathies; Argyll Robertson pupils; stroke in young patient
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL; CSF VDRL (specific); FTA-ABS; responds to IV penicillin

differential.features: Subacute course; basilar meningitis; hydrocephalus; cranial neuropathies; low CSF glucose; risk factors (endemic region, immunocompromise)
differential.tests: CSF AFB smear/culture; TB PCR; adenosine deaminase; chest imaging; low CSF glucose (unlike PACNS)

differential.features: Clinical triad: encephalopathy, branch retinal artery occlusion, sensorineural hearing loss; snowball lesions in corpus callosum on MRI
differential.tests: Fluorescein angiography (branch retinal artery occlusion); audiometry; MRI (corpus callosum lesions); no CSF vasculitis pattern

differential.features: Multifocal infarcts in single vascular territory or bilateral; atrial fibrillation; valvular disease; recent cardiac procedure
differential.tests: Echocardiogram (TTE/TEE); cardiac monitoring; blood cultures if endocarditis suspected; no CSF inflammation

differential.features: String of beads pattern on angiography (similar to vasculitis beading); younger women; renal artery involvement; no CSF abnormalities
differential.tests: CTA/DSA pattern (more regular beading than vasculitis); renal artery imaging; no inflammatory CSF; no vessel wall enhancement

evidence.recommendation: PACNS diagnostic criteria and clinical characterization
Brain biopsy as gold standard for PACNS diagnosis (sensitivity 53-74%)
CSF abnormal in 80-90% of biopsy-confirmed PACNS
Cyclophosphamide plus corticosteroids as standard induction therapy
Large cohort characterization of PACNS (163 patients)
PACNS relapse rate 25-30% and long-term outcomes
Differentiation of PACNS from RCVS by clinical and imaging features
Vessel wall imaging in CNS vasculitis (concentric vs. eccentric enhancement)
Conventional angiography sensitivity and specificity for PACNS
VZV vasculopathy as PACNS mimic; CSF VZV antibody more sensitive than PCR
Azathioprine as maintenance therapy following cyclophosphamide induction
Mycophenolate mofetil as maintenance alternative in PACNS
Rituximab for refractory CNS vasculitis

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (mental status, cranial nerves, motor, sensory, coordination)
monitoring.action: If worsening: urgent MRI; escalate immunotherapy; neurology reassessment; consider ICU transfer
If increasing: urgent re-imaging; consider recurrent ischemia vs. treatment failure

monitoring.frequency: Q6h during IV methylprednisolone; QID during oral prednisone
monitoring.action: Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250 mg/dL
Treat hypertension with IV labetalol or oral antihypertensives; avoid excessive lowering in setting of cerebral ischemia
Fever workup (blood/urine cultures); distinguish infection from disease activity

monitoring.frequency: Daily during acute phase; q48h after stabilization
monitoring.action: Hold immunosuppression if critically low; hematology consult; growth factor support if needed
Adjust medications for renal function; electrolyte repletion
Dose adjustment or hold hepatotoxic medications
Adjust IV fluids; diuretics if fluid overload on steroids

monitoring.frequency: Continuous observation; EEG if clinical seizures
monitoring.action: Escalate ASMs per Section 3A; continuous EEG if subclinical seizures suspected

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (cognition, focal deficits, headache assessment)
monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 6 months; then q3 months x 2 years; then q6 months
monitoring.action: If new deficits or worsening: urgent MRI; repeat LP; reassess treatment; consider relapse

monitoring.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (with MRA and VWI)
monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-induction; then q6 months x 2 years; then annually x 3 years
monitoring.action: New lesions: relapse workup; repeat LP; escalate treatment; consider repeat angiography

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-induction; then as clinically indicated
monitoring.action: Persistent or worsening pleocytosis: treatment failure; reassess diagnosis; escalate therapy

monitoring.frequency: Q2 weeks during cyclophosphamide; monthly on azathioprine/mycophenolate
monitoring.action: Hold or reduce immunosuppression; dose adjust; consider alternative agent

monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 3 months on azathioprine/mycophenolate; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Dose reduction or switch agent; hepatology referral if persistent

monitoring.frequency: Monthly during cyclophosphamide; q3 months on maintenance
monitoring.action: Dose adjustment for renal function; nephrology referral

monitoring.frequency: Monthly during cyclophosphamide; q3 months for 2 years after
monitoring.action: Hematuria: cystoscopy to evaluate for hemorrhagic cystitis or bladder malignancy; hold cyclophosphamide
Rising markers: assess for disease activity vs. infection; clinical correlation required (ESR/CRP often normal in PACNS)

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if steroids >3 months; repeat q1-2 years
monitoring.action: Bisphosphonate therapy; calcium/vitamin D optimization; endocrine referral
Adjust diabetes medications; dietary counseling; endocrine referral

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; then annually while on steroids
monitoring.action: Refer to ophthalmology; adjust steroid therapy if possible
Dose reduce (intermediate) or avoid (deficient) azathioprine
Guide cognitive rehabilitation; adjust treatment; inform return-to-work planning
Immunoglobulin replacement if recurrent infections with hypogammaglobulinemia
Repopulating B-cells may trigger relapse; guide re-dosing timing
Worsening: treatment failure; escalate immunosuppression; consider alternative diagnosis
Adjust antihypertensive therapy; dietary counseling

disposition.criteria: Stable or improving neurologic examination; no new infarcts on follow-up imaging; tolerating oral medications; oral prednisone taper established; outpatient cyclophosphamide infusions arranged; follow-up with neurology within 1-2 weeks; caregiver education completed; no active seizures; adequate home support

New presentation with suspected PACNS requiring urgent workup (LP, MRI, angiography); initiation of IV methylprednisolone; brain biopsy planning; new neurologic deficits; seizures requiring medication adjustment; diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited evaluation

Large territory infarction with risk of herniation; status epilepticus; altered consciousness (GCS <12); severe hypertensive emergency; hemorrhagic transformation; post-brain biopsy monitoring (first 24h); acute clinical deterioration despite treatment; need for continuous EEG monitoring

Conventional angiography or vessel wall imaging not available; neurosurgery for biopsy not available; neuroimmunology or cerebrovascular specialist not available; ICU care required but not available at current facility

Medically stable; significant functional deficits from stroke-like episodes requiring intensive therapy (cognitive, motor, speech); unable to safely return home; expected to benefit from structured rehabilitation program

All patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks post-discharge; rheumatology co-management; infusion center for cyclophosphamide/rituximab; neuropsychology referral; rehabilitation services; laboratory monitoring per protocol
New or worsening neurologic deficits; breakthrough seizures; signs of treatment complication (infection, hemorrhagic cystitis, severe cytopenias); suspected disease relapse
